reviewText:
The Trusted Outlaw, 1937 film

A man enters the cantia and announces an act. A young lady dances, men cheer and applaud. Dan Ward enters and hears the talk. Take that back! There is a fight, Dan wins. Dan plans to return to his home town, marry, and settle down. Molly meets him when he returns. Why does she tremble? A man creeps up on the pair. Dan wants to leave peacefully. A man tries to shoot Dan, Dan is faster with his pistol. Molly rides away. Dan visits the Sheriff to tell what happened. The dead man was one of Swains men. Swain and two of his men arrive. The Sheriff tells Dan that Molly Clark loves Bert Gilmore.

A mine owner, Mr. Pember, wants to hire Dan to guard his payroll. Swain and his gang are after the payroll, they watch the Sheriff and Dan Ward. Bert Gilmore is not afraid of Dan Ward. Then Dan enters the saloon and orders ginger ale. Gilmore challenges him, there is a fight! Dan beats the bigger man. Swain requests a future interview with Dan; he figured out Dans job. The next day Dan goes on his trip and sees a man on a hill signaling. Swains gang closes in on Dan, but Dan eludes them. He is chased by men but takes a detour. One of Swains gang flashes a signal to Swain. The miners demand their pay. Swain stops Dan, who throws down a package then rides off. Its blank paper!

Dan arrives with the hidden money and explains the delay. Dan delivers a letter to Miss Pember. Miss Pember intends to visit her sister-in-law in Yellow Creek. Grogan squeals to Bert Gilmore about Miss Betty Pember. She has been kidnapped by Bert Gilmore. Molly hears Gilmores comments about her! Molly knows how to use her pistol. Dan tries to draw off Swains gang. The miner from Rockville arrive on their horses, they shoot at Swains gang. There is a chase for action. Some of Swains gang fall from their horses. Swain and Dan meet, Dan beats him to the draw! Swain is wounded and captured. Adler and the miners helped Dan. Mr. Pember wants Dan to continue working for him. There will be a happy ending.

This is an interesting story that stretches the limits of the usual Western movie. A man restores his reputation, saves a payroll from robbers, and finds a new romance.

Republic Pictures presents "TRUSTED OUTLAW" (4 May 1937) (52 mins/B&W) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) -- Bob Steele was an American actor --- He was born Robert Adrian Bradbury in 1907 in Portland, Oregon, into a vaudeville family --- Bob's career began to take off for good in 1927, when he was hired by production company Film Booking Offices of America (FBO) to star in a series of Westerns. Bob--who was rechristened Bob Steele at FBO--soon made a name for himself, and in the late 1920s, 1930s and 1940s starred in B-Westerns for almost every minor film studio, including Monogram, Supreme, Tiffany, Syndicate, Republic (including several films of the Three Mesquiteers series) and Producers Releasing Corporation (PRC) (including the initial films of their "Billy the Kid" series)

In the late 1940s and early 1950s, that "new medium" television had many hours to fill and few dollars to fill them --- They re-discovered the B-Western, still a popular mainstay of Saturday afternoon matinees and many cowboy stars thrilled a new audience --- Taking advantage of this rebirth in popularity, publishers brought to the marketplace comic books featuring these western heroes of "Bob Steele" Westerns --- These bimonthly issues were copyrighted in February and April of 1950 by Fawcet Publications --- His career which included nearly 200 feature films, serials and TV appearances --- Steele in his twilight years at the age 59 when he got the part of the cantankerous "Trooper Duffy", in the western comedy series "F Troop" (1965), who at the drop of a hat would give his rendition of fighting "shoulder to shoulder with Davy Crockett at the Alamo" --- Steele retired from the screen in 1973 --- Bob's long career, spanning more than 50 years came to an end in 1988 when he passed away.

Under the production staff of:
Robert North Bradbury  - Director
A.W. Hackel  - Producer
Johnston McCulley  - Book Author
Fred K. Myton  - Screenwriter
George Plympton  - Screenwriter
Bert Longenecker  - Cinematographer
Roy S. Luby  - Editor

The story line and plot, Our scrappy hero Dan Ward (Bob Steele) has the reputation of an outlaw but Mr. Pember (Hal Price) trusts him with the payroll that must get through to his miners --- Jim Swain (Earl Dwire) learns Ward is carrying the money and traps him along the way but Ward tricks him with a fake wad of bills --- But Swain learns Pember's niece Betty Pember (Joan Barclay) is making the return trip and now both her and Ward are in trouble --- Will Bob Steele prove that he's a good guy after all --- Lois January was the official heroine but has jilted Steele for another --- Watch for the surprise ending for this classic sagebrush oater.

the cast includes:
Bob Steele ...  Dan Ward
 Lois January ...  Molly Clark
 Joan Barclay ...  Betty Pember
 Earl Dwire ...  Jim Swain
 Charles King ...  Bert Gilmore (as Charlie King)
 Richard Cramer ...  Rogan, lead hostile miner (as Dick Cramer)
 Hal Price ...  Mr. Pember
 Frank Ball ...  Sheriff Bob Larimer
 Budd Buster ...  Adler, lead friendly miner (as Bud Buster)
 Ernie Adams ...  Duke, Farrell's crony
 Foxy Callahan ...  Barfly
 Joe Dominguez ...  Ramon Jiminez, cantina owner
 Oscar Gahan ...  Guard
 Chick Hannon ...  Henchman
 Ray Henderson ...  Pool Player
 Clyde McClary ...  Bartender Mike & Miner
 Dick Morehead ...  Sanderson
 George Morrell ...  Townsman
 Perry Murdock ...  Farrell, cantina bigmouth
 Horace Murphy ...  Jim, Dan's cantina friend
 Fred Parker ...  Townsman
 Jack Rockwell ...  Henchman
 James Sheridan ...  Red, chief henchman
 Jack C. Smith ...  Townsman
 Al Taylor ...  Miner
 Wally West ...  Cowhand
 Slim Whitaker ...  Sniper Ted Wells

SPECIAL FEATURES:
BIO:
1. Bob Steele (aka: Robert Adrian Bradbury) (Actor)
Date of Birth: 23 January 1907 - Portland, Oregon
Date of Death: 21 December 1988 - Burbank, California

If you crave action, drama and plenty of adventure check out other western double features --- Ask Amazon. Com to carry the volumes as they are not available on Amazon as of yet --- you can order and pick up your copy now from VCI Entertainment

BOB STEELE WESTERN DOUBLE FEATURES:
1. Vol. 1 - Tombstone Terror/Lightnin' Crandall (VCI #7212) (DVD)
2. Vol. 2 - The Brand of Hate/Trusted Outlaw (VCI #7252) (DVD)
3. Vol. 3 - The Arizona Gunfighter/Last of the Warrens (VCI #7261) (DVD)
4. Vol. 4 - Gun Lords of Stirrup Basin'/The Feud Maker (VCI #7275) (DVD)
5. Vol. 5 - Border Phantom/A Demon For Trouble (VCI #7311) (DVD)
6. Vol. 6 - The Kid Ranger/Nevada Buckaroo (VCI #7336) (DVD)
7. Vol. 7 - The Red Rope/Paroled To Die (VCI #7338) (DVD)
8. Vol. 8 - Smokey Smith/Sundown Saunders (VCI #7340) (DVD)
9. Vol. 9 - Doomed At Sundown/The Law Rides (VCI #7344) (DVD)
10. Vol 10 - No Man's Range/Rider of the Law (VCI #7347) (DVD)

CLASSIC WESTERNS - BOB STEELE FOUR FEATURE:
11. Border Phantom, A Demon For Trouble, Trusted Outlaw, Brand of Hate (VCI #5521) (DVD)

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc) and Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") as they have rekindled my interest once again for B-Westerns and Serials --- If you're into the memories of B-Westerns with high drama, this is the one you've been anxiously waiting for --- please stand up and take a bow Western Classics --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 52 min on VHS/DVD ~ Republic Pictures ~ (5/27/2008)
